clusters.title: Trump urges Israel to pardon Netanyahu, sparking concerns over US influence
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump Urges Israel to Pardon Netanyahu

items.title: Trump urges Israel to pardon Netanyahu, sparking concerns over US influence
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump has urged Israel to pardon Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in a corruption case. Netanyahu is the only sitting Israeli prime minister to be indicted, facing charges of fraud, breach of trust, and accepting bribes.
items.content: President Donald Trump has urged Israel to pardon Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in a corruption case. Netanyahu is the only sitting Israeli prime minister to be indicted, facing charges of fraud, breach of trust, and accepting bribes.

items.title: Trump sends letter to Israel’s president requesting pardon for Netanyahu
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump sent a letter to Israel's president requesting he pardon Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.
items.content: US President Donald Trump sent a letter to Israel's president requesting he pardon Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.

items.title: Trump urges Israel's president to pardon Benjamin Netanyahu
items.standfirst: President Herzog's office says he holds Trump "in the highest regard", but that anyone seeking a pardon has to submit a formal request.
items.content: President Herzog's office says he holds Trump "in the highest regard", but that anyone seeking a pardon has to submit a formal request.

items.title: Trump formally asks Israel’s president to pardon Netanyahu after Gaza truce
items.standfirst: US president calls corruption charges against Israeli PM 'unjustified', describing Netanyahu as 'formidable' leader.
items.content: US president calls corruption charges against Israeli PM 'unjustified', describing Netanyahu as 'formidable' leader.

items.title: Trump writes to Israeli president calling for Netanyahu pardon
items.standfirst: Isaac Herzog can pardon convicted criminals in some circumstances, but cases against Israeli PM are ongoingDonald Trump has repeated a request to Israel’s president, Isaac Herzog, for a pardon for Benjamin Netanyahu, who is on trial in three separate corruption cases.The Israeli prime minister has repeatedly denied any wrongdoing in the ongoing court cases. No rulings have been delivered, and his supporters have dismissed the trials as politically motivated. Continue reading...
items.content: Isaac Herzog can pardon convicted criminals in some circumstances, but cases against Israeli PM are ongoingDonald Trump has repeated a request to Israel’s president, Isaac Herzog, for a pardon for Benjamin Netanyahu, who is on trial in three separate corruption cases.The Israeli prime minister has repeatedly denied any wrongdoing in the ongoing court cases. No rulings have been delivered, and his supporters have dismissed the trials as politically motivated. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump escalates campaign to pardon Netanyahu with letter to Israel’s president
items.standfirst: Unprecedented interventions seek to end prime minister’s long-running corruption trial
items.content: Unprecedented interventions seek to end prime minister’s long-running corruption trial

items.title: Israeli president says he can't pardon Netanyahu on Trump's request alone
items.standfirst: Israel's president says Trump sent him a letter asking him to pardon Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who's on trial in three separate corruption cases.
items.content: Israel's president says Trump sent him a letter asking him to pardon Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who's on trial in three separate corruption cases.

items.title: Trump sends letter to Israeli president asking him to pardon Netanyahu
items.standfirst: Israeli President Issac Herzog on Wednesday said he received a letter from US President Donald Trump asking him to pardon Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who is on trial in three corruption cases. In the letter Trump wrote that the legal proceedings against Netanyahu were "political, unjustified prosecution".
items.content: Israeli President Issac Herzog on Wednesday said he received a letter from US President Donald Trump asking him to pardon Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who is on trial in three corruption cases. In the letter Trump wrote that the legal proceedings against Netanyahu were "political, unjustified prosecution".

items.title: Trump asks Israeli president to 'fully pardon' Netanyahu in corruption trial
items.standfirst: Donald Trump has sent a letter to the Israeli president urging him to "fully pardon" Benjamin Netanyahu in his long-running corruption trial.
items.content: Donald Trump has sent a letter to the Israeli president urging him to "fully pardon" Benjamin Netanyahu in his long-running corruption trial.

ai_summary: Donald Trump urged Israel to pardon Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in a corruption case.
Netanyahu faces charges of fraud, breach of trust, and accepting bribes, which he denies.
Trump sent a letter to Israel's president requesting the pardon for Netanyahu.
The Israeli president's office stated a formal request is needed for a pardon.
Some sources describe the charges against Netanyahu as politically motivated.

clusters.title: House prepares to vote on bill to end government shutdown after 43 days
clusters.neutral_headline: House Prepares to Vote on Bill to End Government Shutdown

items.title: House prepares to vote on bill to end government shutdown after 43 days
items.standfirst: The House is returning to vote on a Senate-passed bill that would end the longest government shutdown in U.S. history. Follow live updates here.
items.content: The House is returning to vote on a Senate-passed bill that would end the longest government shutdown in U.S. history. Follow live updates here.

items.title: White House slams focus on new Epstein emails referencing Trump as shutdown conclusion nears
items.standfirst: White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt blasted questions about a new set of Jeffrey Epstein's emails released by the House Oversight Committee that appear to reference President Trump. This comes as Congress appears ready to end the government shutdown. CBS News' Aaron Navarro reports.
items.content: White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt blasted questions about a new set of Jeffrey Epstein's emails released by the House Oversight Committee that appear to reference President Trump. This comes as Congress appears ready to end the government shutdown. CBS News' Aaron Navarro reports.

items.title: Trump ‘spent hours’ at Epstein’s house with victim of sex trafficking, email alleges

items.content: House Democrats release new communications from late paedophile

items.title: House Oversight Democrats release new Epstein emails that reference Trump
items.standfirst: Democrats from the House Oversight Committee released a set of Jeffrey Epstein's emails that appear to reference President Trump. CBS News' Katrina Kaufman reports.
items.content: Democrats from the House Oversight Committee released a set of Jeffrey Epstein's emails that appear to reference President Trump. CBS News' Katrina Kaufman reports.

items.title: Flight cancellations ease, hitting lowest rate in almost a week, with end to the shutdown in sight
items.standfirst: Flight disruptions eased on Wednesday before House lawmakers were set to vote on a spending bill that would end the longest-ever government shutdown.
items.content: Flight disruptions eased on Wednesday before House lawmakers were set to vote on a spending bill that would end the longest-ever government shutdown.

items.title: White House vows Trump will sign ‘good-faith’ shutdown-ending bill
items.standfirst: The White House committed in writing Wednesday that President Donald Trump will sign the bill to end the longest government shutdown in U.S. history once the House passes it. In a statement of administration policy, the Trump administration urged every lawmaker to back the measure, which would…
items.content: The White House committed in writing Wednesday that President Donald Trump will sign the bill to end the longest government shutdown in U.S. history once the House passes it. In a statement of administration policy, the Trump administration urged every lawmaker to back the measure, which would…

items.title: FAA holds 6% flight cuts ahead of House vote
items.standfirst: The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) kept flight cancellations at 6% on Wednesday as the House is preparing to vote on a Senate-approved bill to end the government shutdown. President Donald Trum...
items.content: The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) kept flight cancellations at 6% on Wednesday as the House is preparing to vote on a Senate-approved bill to end the government shutdown. President Donald Trum...

items.title: Epstein said Trump "knew about the girls" in 2019 email, House Democrats say
items.standfirst: The three emails appear to be exchanges between convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell, as well as the author Michael Wolff and Epstein.
items.content: The three emails appear to be exchanges between convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell, as well as the author Michael Wolff and Epstein.

items.title: New emails from Epstein mentioning Trump released by House Democrats
items.standfirst: House Democrats on Wednesday released emails from Jeffrey Epstein referencing President Trump, who has denied any knowledge of the convicted sex offender's crimes. In a 2019 email, Epstein said Mr. Trump "knew about the girls as he asked ghislaine to stop." CBS News' Nancy Cordes has more.
items.content: House Democrats on Wednesday released emails from Jeffrey Epstein referencing President Trump, who has denied any knowledge of the convicted sex offender's crimes. In a 2019 email, Epstein said Mr. Trump "knew about the girls as he asked ghislaine to stop." CBS News' Nancy Cordes has more.

items.title: Flight cancellations, air travel delays could persist after shutdown ends
items.standfirst: Travelers may still have to deal with flight issues even when the government shutdown ends, Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy said.
items.content: Travelers may still have to deal with flight issues even when the government shutdown ends, Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy said.

items.title: Trump ‘spent hours’ with victim at Epstein’s house, email alleges
items.standfirst: Epstein emails released by US House Democrats provide further proof of ties between US president and sex offender.
items.content: Epstein emails released by US House Democrats provide further proof of ties between US president and sex offender.

items.title: What’s Being Said About the US Govt Shutdown
items.standfirst: Misinformation is spreading fast amid the US government shutdown. We break down the facts as the House prepares to vote.
items.content: Misinformation is spreading fast amid the US government shutdown. We break down the facts as the House prepares to vote.

items.title: Trump live: US House Democrats release Epstein emails before shutdown vote
items.standfirst: The House of Representatives will hold a session to vote on legislation to end the longest shutdown in US history.
items.content: The House of Representatives will hold a session to vote on legislation to end the longest shutdown in US history.

items.title: Epstein emails released by Democrats claim Trump ‘knew about the girls’
items.standfirst: Convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein suggested that Donald Trump was aware of the financier's sexual abuse and definitely "knew about the girls", according to emails released by Democrats in the US House of Representatives Wednesday. This comes as Democrats have been trying to force a vote that would compel the publication of the full Epstein case files.
items.content: Convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein suggested that Donald Trump was aware of the financier's sexual abuse and definitely "knew about the girls", according to emails released by Democrats in the US House of Representatives Wednesday. This comes as Democrats have been trying to force a vote that would compel the publication of the full Epstein case files.

items.title: New Epstein emails appear to reveal more Trump ties
items.standfirst: Democrats on the House Oversight Committee have released several emails from the estate of convicted sex trafficker Jeffrey Epstein that refer to President Trump.
items.content: Democrats on the House Oversight Committee have released several emails from the estate of convicted sex trafficker Jeffrey Epstein that refer to President Trump.(Image credit: Chip Somodevilla)

items.title: Flight issues could linger after shutdown. And, Google's lawsuit targeting scammers
items.standfirst: Even if the government shutdown ends this week, flight disruptions are expected to linger. And, Google has launched a lawsuit targeting text message scammers.
items.content: Even if the government shutdown ends this week, flight disruptions are expected to linger. And, Google has launched a lawsuit targeting text message scammers.(Image credit: Win McNamee)

ai_summary: The House is voting on a Senate-passed bill to end the government shutdown.
The shutdown is the longest in U.S. history, lasting 43 days.
White House officials stated Trump will sign the bill once passed by the House.
The FAA kept flight cancellations at 6% ahead of the House vote.
New Epstein emails referencing Trump were released by House Democrats.

clusters.title: Is US 'dramatic show of force' designed to scare military into removing Maduro, send him into exile?
clusters.neutral_headline: US Military Buildup Near Venezuela Raises Tensions

items.title: Is US 'dramatic show of force' designed to scare military into removing Maduro, send him into exile?
items.standfirst: A US aircraft carrier strike group has arrived in Latin America, escalating a military buildup Venezuela has warned could trigger a full-blown conflict as it announced its own "massive" deployment. The USS Gerald R. Ford's deployment was ordered nearly three weeks ago with the stated goal of helping to counter drug trafficking in the region. For in-depth analysis and a deeper perspective, Angela Diffley welcomes Christopher Sabatini, Senior Research Fellow at Chatham House. Mr. Sabatini warns that the Trump administration is seeking to dislodge Maduro from power." He insists that Venezuela does not even produce fentanyl and "there's no reason why the US would be so concerned with drug traffickers leaving Venezuela."
items.content: A US aircraft carrier strike group has arrived in Latin America, escalating a military buildup Venezuela has warned could trigger a full-blown conflict as it announced its own "massive" deployment. The USS Gerald R. Ford's deployment was ordered nearly three weeks ago with the stated goal of helping to counter drug trafficking in the region. For in-depth analysis and a deeper perspective, Angela Diffley welcomes Christopher Sabatini, Senior Research Fellow at Chatham House. Mr. Sabatini warns that the Trump administration is seeking to dislodge Maduro from power." He insists that Venezuela does not even produce fentanyl and "there's no reason why the US would be so concerned with drug traffickers leaving Venezuela."

items.title: Venezuela conducts military exercise as largest U.S. carrier gets closer to the Caribbean
items.standfirst: Venezuela is conducting a massive military exercise as tensions rise near its shores. This comes as the USS Gerald R. Ford enters the Southern Command, and as U.S. strikes against apparent drug-carrying vessels continue. CBS News' Charlie D'Agata reports.
items.content: Venezuela is conducting a massive military exercise as tensions rise near its shores. This comes as the USS Gerald R. Ford enters the Southern Command, and as U.S. strikes against apparent drug-carrying vessels continue. CBS News' Charlie D'Agata reports.

items.title: Venezuela mobilizes as top US warship nears
items.standfirst: What happened The USS Gerald R. Ford, the largest and most advanced U.S. aircraft carrier, and its three accompanying warships entered the Caribbean region Tuesday, adding to President Donald Trump’s unusual buildup of naval might off the coast of Venezuela. Pentagon spokesperson Sean Parnell said…
items.content: What happened The USS Gerald R. Ford, the largest and most advanced U.S. aircraft carrier, and its three accompanying warships entered the Caribbean region Tuesday, adding to President Donald Trump’s unusual buildup of naval might off the coast of Venezuela. Pentagon spokesperson Sean Parnell said…

items.title: Venezuela: Tensions rise as US sends world's largest aircraft carrier
items.standfirst: A US aircraft carrier strike group arrived in Latin America Tuesday, escalating a military buildup Venezuela has warned could trigger a full-blown conflict as it announced its own "massive" deployment. The USS Gerald R. Ford, the world's largest aircraft carrier, entered an area under control of the US Naval Forces Southern Command, which encompasses Latin America and the Caribbean. The vessel's deployment was ordered nearly three weeks ago, with the stated goal of helping to counter drug trafficking in the region.
items.content: A US aircraft carrier strike group arrived in Latin America Tuesday, escalating a military buildup Venezuela has warned could trigger a full-blown conflict as it announced its own "massive" deployment. The USS Gerald R. Ford, the world's largest aircraft carrier, entered an area under control of the US Naval Forces Southern Command, which encompasses Latin America and the Caribbean. The vessel's deployment was ordered nearly three weeks ago, with the stated goal of helping to counter drug trafficking in the region.

items.title: US aircraft carrier group arrives in Caribbean as tensions with Venezuela rise
items.standfirst: The US Navy's Gerald R Ford aircraft carrier is considered the world's largest warship.
items.content: The US Navy's Gerald R Ford aircraft carrier is considered the world's largest warship.

ai_summary: A U.S. aircraft carrier strike group arrived in Latin America, near Venezuela.
Venezuela has warned the buildup could trigger a full-blown conflict.
The USS Gerald R. Ford entered the Caribbean region with warships.
The U.S. military buildup is unusual, according to some reports.
Venezuela is conducting military exercises amid rising tensions.

clusters.title: India confirms deadly Delhi car blast being treated as terror incident
clusters.neutral_headline: India Confirms Delhi Car Blast as Terror Incident

items.title: India confirms deadly Delhi car blast being treated as terror incident
items.standfirst: Cabinet says explosion near Red Fort that killed 12 is suspected to have been perpetrated by ‘anti-national forces’India has confirmed it is treating the explosion that killed 12 people outside Delhi’s Red Fort on Monday as a “terror incident” perpetrated by “anti-national forces”.The statement by the cabinet, led by the prime minister, Narendra Modi, confirmed mounting speculation that a terrorist attack was behind the blast that took place during peak time in one of the capital’s busiest areas and outside one of India’s major landmarks. Continue reading...
items.content: Cabinet says explosion near Red Fort that killed 12 is suspected to have been perpetrated by ‘anti-national forces’India has confirmed it is treating the explosion that killed 12 people outside Delhi’s Red Fort on Monday as a “terror incident” perpetrated by “anti-national forces”.The statement by the cabinet, led by the prime minister, Narendra Modi, confirmed mounting speculation that a terrorist attack was behind the blast that took place during peak time in one of the capital’s busiest areas and outside one of India’s major landmarks. Continue reading...

items.title: Indian government calls deadly car explosion a terror attack by ‘anti-national forces’
items.standfirst: Earlier Wednesday, authorities said several suspects had been arrested in the disputed Kashmir region as part of the investigation into the blast Monday near the historic Red Fort monument that killed eight people and injured several others.
items.content: Earlier Wednesday, authorities said several suspects had been arrested in the disputed Kashmir region as part of the investigation into the blast Monday near the historic Red Fort monument that killed eight people and injured several others.

items.title: Pakistan opens investigation into Islamabad terror attack
items.standfirst: Pakistani ministers attribute deadly suicide attack to Indian state terrorism but India denies claimPakistan has opened an investigation into the suicide attack that killed 12 people outside district court buildings in Islamabad, after the prime minister made unsubstantiated claims that “Indian state terrorism” was behind the blast.The attack took place in the middle of the day on Tuesday as the area was thrumming with people. The bomber made several attempts to get inside the buildings before detonating a device next to a police car, killing 12 people and injuring 27. Continue reading...
items.content: Pakistani ministers attribute deadly suicide attack to Indian state terrorism but India denies claimPakistan has opened an investigation into the suicide attack that killed 12 people outside district court buildings in Islamabad, after the prime minister made unsubstantiated claims that “Indian state terrorism” was behind the blast.The attack took place in the middle of the day on Tuesday as the area was thrumming with people. The bomber made several attempts to get inside the buildings before detonating a device next to a police car, killing 12 people and injuring 27. Continue reading...

items.title: Suicide bombing in Islamabad kills 12, says Pakistan's interior minister
items.standfirst: Mohsin Naqvi says the bomber tried to gain entry to a court complex but was unable to get inside.
items.content: Mohsin Naqvi says the bomber tried to gain entry to a court complex but was unable to get inside.

items.title: Indian police investigating fatal Delhi car blast under anti-terror law
items.standfirst: Statements from government ministers suggest they do not see explosion that killed eight people as an accidentIndian police are investigating a car explosion that killed eight people outside Delhi’s historic Red Fort under an anti-terror law, as they focus on the final movements of the vehicle involved.The explosion on Monday occurred at about 7pm, a peak time when Delhi’s old city is usually packed with people and traffic. Continue reading...
items.content: Statements from government ministers suggest they do not see explosion that killed eight people as an accidentIndian police are investigating a car explosion that killed eight people outside Delhi’s historic Red Fort under an anti-terror law, as they focus on the final movements of the vehicle involved.The explosion on Monday occurred at about 7pm, a peak time when Delhi’s old city is usually packed with people and traffic. Continue reading...

items.title: Pakistan Taliban claim responsibility for deadly terror attack in Islamabad
items.standfirst: Defence minister says country is in ‘state of war’ after suicide blast kills 12 and injures 27 outside court buildingsAt least 12 people have been killed in a suicide blast in Islamabad carried out by the Pakistan Taliban, as the country’s defence minister said a deadly surge in terror attacks had put the country in a “state of war”.The explosion, which was confirmed as a suicide attack by several government ministers, took place outside district court buildings in the capital on Tuesday at about 12.30pm. The area is usually heavily crowded with lawyers and litigants attending trials. Continue reading...
items.content: Defence minister says country is in ‘state of war’ after suicide blast kills 12 and injures 27 outside court buildingsAt least 12 people have been killed in a suicide blast in Islamabad carried out by the Pakistan Taliban, as the country’s defence minister said a deadly surge in terror attacks had put the country in a “state of war”.The explosion, which was confirmed as a suicide attack by several government ministers, took place outside district court buildings in the capital on Tuesday at about 12.30pm. The area is usually heavily crowded with lawyers and litigants attending trials. Continue reading...

items.title: At least 12 killed after suicide bombing in Pakistan
items.standfirst: At least 12 people have been killed in a suicide bombing outside the gates of a court in Pakistan's capital of Islamabad, the country's interior minister has said.
items.content: At least 12 people have been killed in a suicide bombing outside the gates of a court in Pakistan's capital of Islamabad, the country's interior minister has said.

ai_summary: India confirmed the Delhi car explosion is a terror incident.
The explosion killed 12 people near the Red Fort.
The government suspects "anti-national forces" perpetrated the attack.
Pakistan is investigating a suicide attack in Islamabad.
Indian police are investigating the Delhi blast under anti-terror laws.

clusters.title: French-Algerian writer Boualem Sansal pardoned and to be released from prison
clusters.neutral_headline: Algeria Pardons French-Algerian Writer Boualem Sansal

items.title: French-Algerian writer Boualem Sansal pardoned and to be released from prison
items.standfirst: Eighty-one year-old, who has prostate cancer, can now be transferred from Algeria to Germany for medical treatmentThe French-Algerian writer Boualem Sansal has been pardoned and is to be released from prison, the Algerian presidential office said in a statement on Wednesday.The move, which will mean Sansal can be transferred to Germany for medical treatment, comes after the German president, Frank-Walter Steinmeier, urged Algeria to free Sansal. Continue reading...
items.content: Eighty-one year-old, who has prostate cancer, can now be transferred from Algeria to Germany for medical treatmentThe French-Algerian writer Boualem Sansal has been pardoned and is to be released from prison, the Algerian presidential office said in a statement on Wednesday.The move, which will mean Sansal can be transferred to Germany for medical treatment, comes after the German president, Frank-Walter Steinmeier, urged Algeria to free Sansal. Continue reading...

items.title: Algeria pardons French-Algerian author Sansal after year-long imprisonment
items.standfirst: Algeria ’s president granted a humanitarian pardon to the French-Algerian novelist Boualem Sansal on Wednesday, releasing him after a year-long imprisonment that sparked widespread criticism.
items.content: Algeria ’s president granted a humanitarian pardon to the French-Algerian novelist Boualem Sansal on Wednesday, releasing him after a year-long imprisonment that sparked widespread criticism.

items.title: Algeria’s president pardons jailed writer Boualem Sansal
items.standfirst: The pardon of the 81-year-old author comes after Germany appealed for his release on 'humanitarian grounds'.
items.content: The pardon of the 81-year-old author comes after Germany appealed for his release on 'humanitarian grounds'.

items.title: Algeria pardons Franco-Algerian writer Boualem Sansal
items.standfirst: Algerian President Abdelmadjid Tebboune has pardoned French-Algerian writer Boualem Sansal following a request from German President Frank-Walter Steinmeier. Sansal, 81, was arrested last year and sentenced to five years for undermining national unity, charges he denied, insisting he never intended to offend Algeria or its institutions.
items.content: Algerian President Abdelmadjid Tebboune has pardoned French-Algerian writer Boualem Sansal following a request from German President Frank-Walter Steinmeier. Sansal, 81, was arrested last year and sentenced to five years for undermining national unity, charges he denied, insisting he never intended to offend Algeria or its institutions.

items.title: Algeria pardons French-Algerian writer Boualem Sansal
items.standfirst: Algeria’s president on Wednesday granted a humanitarian pardon to French-Algerian novelist Boualem Sansal following a German request for his release. The 81-year-old writer, whose year-long imprisonment sparked widespread criticism, was en route to Germany for medical treatment, German President Frank-Walter Steinmeier said.
items.content: Algeria’s president on Wednesday granted a humanitarian pardon to French-Algerian novelist Boualem Sansal following a German request for his release. The 81-year-old writer, whose year-long imprisonment sparked widespread criticism, was en route to Germany for medical treatment, German President Frank-Walter Steinmeier said.

ai_summary: Algeria pardoned French-Algerian writer Boualem Sansal after a year in prison.
The pardon allows Sansal to be transferred to Germany for medical treatment.
The German president requested Sansal's release on humanitarian grounds.
Sansal was arrested and sentenced for undermining national unity.
The writer's imprisonment sparked widespread criticism.

items.content: President Donald Trump said he has an obligation to proceed with his threatened $1 billion lawsuit against the BBC for editing a speech he made on Jan. 6.

items.standfirst: The US president indicates he will go ahead with a lawsuit against the BBC over how his speech was presented by Panorama.
items.content: The US president indicates he will go ahead with a lawsuit against the BBC over how his speech was presented by Panorama.

items.title: Trump threatens to sue BBC for $1 billion over January 6 speech edit
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump has threatened to sue the BBC for $1 billion, alleging that the British public broadcaster attempted to “interfere in the presidential election” last year by editing his January 6th speech. NBC News’ Raf Sanchez has the details, as two top executives have already resigned amid mounting pressure on the organization.
items.content: President Donald Trump has threatened to sue the BBC for $1 billion, alleging that the British public broadcaster attempted to “interfere in the presidential election” last year by editing his January 6th speech. NBC News’ Raf Sanchez has the details, as two top executives have already resigned amid mounting pressure on the organization.

ai_summary: Donald Trump says he has an obligation to sue the BBC.

The BBC is prepared to apologize to Trump to resolve the legal threat.
Trump is threatening a $1 billion lawsuit against the BBC.
The lawsuit alleges the BBC attempted to interfere in the election.

clusters.neutral_headline: Protesters Clash with Security at COP30 Climate Talks

items.title: 🚨 #COP30: Rare #clashes between #Indigenous protesters and #security guards
items.standfirst: 💥 Dozens of Indigenous protesters forced their way into the COP30 climate summit venue on Tuesday and clashed with security guards at the entrance to demand climate action and forest protection. 📣 Some waved flags with slogans calling for land rights or carried signs saying: "Our land is not for sale." 👮‍♂️ Calm was quickly restored and the protesters dispersed shortly after the clashes.
items.content: 💥 Dozens of Indigenous protesters forced their way into the COP30 climate summit venue on Tuesday and clashed with security guards at the entrance to demand climate action and forest protection. 📣 Some waved flags with slogans calling for land rights or carried signs saying: "Our land is not for sale." 👮‍♂️ Calm was quickly restored and the protesters dispersed shortly after the clashes.

items.standfirst: Skims plans to use new capital to broaden its intimates lines, and expand further into apparel and activewear Skims, founded by reality TV star and entrepreneur Kim Kardashian along with CEO Jens Grede, said on Wednesday it had raised $225mn in new capital, valuing the shapewear label at $5bn.Kardashian’s ventures, including her cosmetics brand SKKN, have attracted young shoppers and benefited from her vast social media following.
